posts.cooked:
Ever had a tough time working on code because a computer isn‚Äôt setup with wpilib tools and you don‚Äôt have admin permissions? You don‚Äôt need it anymore!

You can now compile or modify your robot code (with intelisense!) using github Codespaces. Before we start you should note that there is 60hrs free of 2 core codespaces per month and even if your project is under an organization it will be charged against your account, NOT THE ORGANIZATION . We have made a example of this on our mentor example code on github.

You can delete codespaces after you‚Äôre done with them by going to Code->Codespaces->On current branch->...->Delete .

To create a codespace you go to Code->Codespaces->Create codespace on main .

Spin up fully configured dev environments in the cloud that start in seconds.

Codespaces seem perfect for teams where not all programmers have their own laptops and can install the tools on them. To set it up for an FRC project all you have to do is create the file from the root of the repository .devcontainer/devcontainer.json which contains

As is done here .

Hopefully this helps many teams this season!

link_counts.title: Github Codespaces (Programming in your browser for FRC) 2023 Update

Team 5113 is working on an analogues system (based on the ‚Äúthin client‚Äù archetype), hoping to report back soon!

Does the image you use support viewing the sim gui?

Gitpod has a similar number of free hours and one of their base images comes with automatic browser based vnc if a gui is launched. Using a similar image on codespaces would be invaluable.

Vasista:

VSCode itself implements something similar for viewing the UI, so should be entirely possible vscode/.devcontainer at main ¬∑ microsoft/vscode ¬∑ GitHub

Regarding the plugin installation, I‚Äôve heard that having the WPILib plugin live in the plugin store may or may not continue ( @Thad_House ?). If its not available, this may require some changes here in the near future, and maybe a simple docker container.

nstrike:

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked:
Will_Toth:

Regarding the plugin installation, I‚Äôve heard that having the WPILib plugin live in the plugin store may or may not continue

We publish it to the store just so someone else doesn‚Äôt publish an unofficial version with the same name. We don‚Äôt monitor or maintain the store version because we recommend teams use the WPILib installer‚Äôs version of VS Code instead. We do that because the installer must modify the VS Code install to make intellisense work. In other words, using a vanilla install of VS Code with the store plugin is broken due to Gradle-isms.

posts.name: Matt Soucy (he/him)
posts.cooked:
Out of curiosity, and sorry for pulling the thread slightly of topic, what kind of of modifications does it do to the VS Code installation itself? I looked in the installer repo but am not familiar with the layout. (You meant the Avalonia installer, not the plugin, right?)

EDIT: I found this , so it looks like it‚Äôs specifically things in the user settings file?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
Correct.  You can find this in a local install in C:\Users\Public\wpilib\2023\vscode\data\user-data\User\settings.json.  What this does is:

Set java.home, JAVA_HOME, and PATH to point to our installed JDK

Disable auto-updates

Disable system certificates

link_counts.title: New for 2023 ‚Äî FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked:
There‚Äôs nothing related to IntelliSense needed for a vanilla install vs the wpilib install, other then the forced jdk, which sometimes can break IntelliSense.

The primary reason is to force a known good jdk, as well as disable updates and disable system certs as said above.

Forcing a known good jdk was very important the first year, and is still important as invalid jdk versions (both too high and too low) can break builds.

Disabling updates is important because there have been cases in the past where vscode updates have broken the extension, which is hard to debug, and really annoying on our end.

The certificate thing is probably not as necessary anymore, it was added a few years back when sites were changing tls versions and that broke things.

These things, plus the local maven cache are the main reasons we really recommend the installer. It limits the amount of configurations we need to support.

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: I understand where it coming from but in the same way, u know some people are going to prefer using vanilla VScode and it would really be super basic to continue to update the extension store. You can still put in the description that it‚Äôs recommended to use the WPI version of VScode with still making the extension more accessible.

It would be, but until that happens I have a work around I posted here.
